Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
M DCCC LXXXIX
M DCCC LXXXIX
M DCCC LXXXIX
M DCCC LXXXIX
line: Preface.

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
M DCCC LXXXIX
M DCCC LXXXIX
line: The epic poem of Gu-drun is one of the most important early literary

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: works of the German race. It is attributed to the latter part of the

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: twelfth or the beginning of the thirteenth century, and to a date a

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: little subsequent to that of the Nibelungen Lied. It was first brought to

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: the notice of the modern world in the year 1817, the only original

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: manuscript now known to exist having been discovered about that time in

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: the castle Ambras in the Tyrol, among other manuscripts which had been

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: collected by the Emperor Maximilian I. (1493-1519). The manuscript is now

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: in the Imperial Library at Vienna. It has been several times edited and

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: printed in the original Middle High German, with critical annotations;

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: various translations into modern German have also been published: but so

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: far as I can learn, no complete metrical version in the English language

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: has been made public.

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
M DCCC LXXXIX
line: The name of the author is unknown; it is generally thought to have been

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: constructed, in great measure, from earlier legends which had been

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: repeated by wandering singers. According to the late Karl Bartsch, the

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: distinguished critic and editor of Mediæval German literature, the tale

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: shows affinity to legends of the Scalds of Norway and Denmark, and to

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: those of the Shetland Isles. Traces of resemblance are said to be found

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: among the relics of Anglo-Saxon literature. The supposition that the poem

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: was constructed from various early legends explains some of the

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: marvellous incidents of the tale, and those chronological inconsistencies

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: where the rude habits and ideas of earlier times are combined with the

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: later knightly usages of the Middle Ages and with Christian belief.

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
M DCCC LXXXIX
line: The scene of the poem is laid principally on the shores of the North Sea,

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: and includes Ireland and Normandy, as well as Holland, Denmark, and

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: Friesland. Very vague ideas of geography were, however, entertained by

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: the poet. Some names of places are thought to be fabulous, and critics

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: disagree with regard to the modern countries designated by other names

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: used.

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
M DCCC LXXXIX
line: The poem is founded upon the themes of love and war, and properly

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: consists of three parts. The first portion, embracing four tales, relates

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: the adventures of Hagen, the grandfather of Gu-drun; the second part

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: gives the story of the wooing and abduction of Hilda, his daughter, the

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: mother of Gu-drun. The proper story of Gu-drun begins only with the ninth

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: tale.

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
M DCCC LXXXIX
line: The narrative gives a vivid picture of the ideas, manners, and customs of

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: the age of the author; of the dwellings, dress, and ornaments in use; of

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: the weapons and warfare; of the ships and sea-life; and of the

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: tournaments and court festivities. From it we see the nature of the

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: intellectual amusement enjoyed by the northern nations, at that period of

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: their mental development when literary entertainment in the modern sense

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: was yet unknown, and its place was supplied by listening to the recitals

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: of wandering bards.

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
M DCCC LXXXIX
line: Modern German critics agree in assigning a high literary value to the

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: poem of Gu-drun, and compare it not unfavorably with the Nibelungen Lied.

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: Bartsch, the critic above named, says: "The general impression which the

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: poem gives is one of greater beauty, though not always of equal grandeur

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: with that of the Nibelungen; it is a worthy companion-piece. The two are

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: justly compared, as are the Iliad and the Odyssey. In the Nibelungen as

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: in the Iliad the fate of a whole people is decided by the sword, and the

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: ruling house, consisting of noble heroes, meets destruction before our

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: eyes; but the conquerors do not fully rejoice in their success. The whole

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: breathes a tragic spirit, even more than the Greek epic. '_Nach Freude

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: Leid_'--'after joy comes sorrow'--is the earnest tone throughout.

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: Gu-drun, like the Odyssey, closes more tenderly and in a spirit of

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: reconciliation. Although pitiless fate has destroyed the happiness of

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: those for whom the poet has awakened our sympathy, and we see a noble

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: being suffer in the most shameful manner, yet we are sustained by hope,

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: and a happy end compensates for woes endured. '_Aus Leid

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: Freude_'--'sorrows end in joy'--is the final conclusion.... All the

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: characters are worked out in the most minute and careful manner, and are

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: developed consistently.... The best traits of the German nature, fearless

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: bravery, unfaltering fidelity, and unswerving integrity, are presented.

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: The nobility of a feminine soul which, inspired by pure love, in the

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: distress of a hard captivity, preserves its fidelity to its beloved,

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: perhaps in no poem of the German middle ages is so strikingly shown as in

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: the character of Gu-drun.... The descriptions both of battle and scenery

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: are masterly, and are painted with a few decisive strokes."

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
M DCCC LXXXIX
line: The metrical form of Gu-drun is similar to that of the Nibelungen. In

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: both, the accentuation is determined by the logical sense, as in prose,

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: and not always by the number of syllables, as in most modern verse. In

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: both, the lines are metrically divided, giving three accents to each

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: half-line of the stanza, except in the fourth line, in which Gu-drun

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: differs from the Nibelungen in having five accents instead of four on the

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: concluding half-line.

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
M DCCC LXXXIX
line: The translator has adhered to the original rhythm, and has endeavored in

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: each stanza to convey strictly the ideas of the author, being careful not

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: to introduce anything, in thought or simile, foreign to the poem, and, as

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: far as the verse would permit, to give a verbal rendering.

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
M DCCC LXXXIX
line: The translation has been made from Bartsch's edition of the original

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: Middle High German (Brockhaus, Leipzig, 1874). He, like the other

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: editors, has supplied some omissions in the manuscript, an instance of

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: which may be seen in the sixth line of the fac-simile given. The drawings

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: introduced are copied from mediæval German printed books.

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
M DCCC LXXXIX
line: I wish to acknowledge my obligation to my brother for careful revision

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
line: and for many important improvements throughout the translation.

Poem Title: M DCCC LXXXIX
M. P. N.
line: M. P. N.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
M. P. N.
line: Boston, 1889.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
M. P. N.
M. P. N.
M. P. N.
M. P. N.
line: Contents.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
M. P. N.
M. P. N.
line: Tale I. Sigeband, king of Ireland, after the death of his father,

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: marries a princess of Norway, who bears him a son, Hagen.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: During the celebration of a court festival, Hagen, now

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: seven years old, while outside the castle in the care of

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: his attendants, is caught up by a griffin, and borne to

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: his nest in a distant land.   Stanzas 1-66.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Tale II. Hagen, falling from the grasp of one of the young

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: griffins, crawls into a cave, where he finds three young

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: daughters of kings, who had also been carried off by the

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: griffins. He grows up in their company. At last, one day,

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: he wanders with them to the seashore, where he finds a

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: ship whose master, a lord from Karadie, he persuades to

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: rescue them from their exile.   67-113.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Tale III. The master of the ship inquires of Hagen and the

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: maidens concerning their country, and learns that Hagen

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: is the son of an old enemy. He threatens to keep him as a

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: hostage, but Hagen seizes thirty of the sailors, and

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: flings them into the sea, and compels the others to steer

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: towards his home. There, he sends messengers to announce

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: his arrival to his father and mother, who come down to

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: the shore to meet him.   114-150.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Tale IV. Hagen reconciles his father to the men who had brought

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: him home, and receives from his father the government of

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: the kingdom. He marries one of the three maidens, Hilda,

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: from India. She gives birth to a daughter, likewise named

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Hilda. When she is grown up, her many suitors are

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: rejected by her father.   151-203.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Tale V. Hettel, king of the Hegelings, a suitor for Hilda,

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: summons his vassals, Wâ-te, Horant, and Fru-te, and sends

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: them to obtain her for his wife. They go, purporting to

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: be merchants, carrying seven hundred warriors concealed

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: in the hold of the ship. They send rich gifts to Hagen,

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: and at the request of his daughter, Hilda, they are

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: kindly received at court.   204-371.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Tale VI. Horant delights the court with his singing, and he with

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: his friend Morunc are introduced to the bower of Hilda.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: He tells her of Hettel's suit, which she, charmed by the

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: singing of Horant, receives with favor. They invite her

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: to visit their ship, with her father and mother, and the

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: invitation is accepted.   372-439.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Tale VII. Hilda, with her father and mother and her maidens,

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: rides down to the shore; she and the maidens go on board

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: the ship. While Hagen's attention is occupied, the vessel

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: sets sail, and they arrive in Hettel's land.   440-486.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Tale VIII. Hagen and his warriors follow in their ships, in order

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: to rescue Hilda, and reach the Hegeling land: a battle

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: takes place on the seashore. At Hilda's entreaty, peace

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: is made, and Hagen consents to her marriage with Hettel.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Hagen returns home, leaving Hilda and her maidens in

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Hettel's kingdom.   487-562.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Tale IX. Wâ-te, Horant, and the other vassals of Hettel go back

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: to their homes. Hilda bears to Hettel a son, Ortwin, and

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: a daughter, Gu-drun, who is afterwards sought by

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Siegfried, king of Moorland. He is rejected by her

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: father, Hettel, and retires in anger.   563-586.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Tale X. Hartmut, a Norman prince, son of Ludwig and Gerlind,

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: hears of the beauty of Gu-drun, and resolves to woo her.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Messengers are dispatched with letters, but receive a

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: forbidding answer.   587-616.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Tale XI. Herwic, king of Sealand, sends suitors for the hand of

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Gu-drun, who are also rejected. Hartmut of Normandy comes

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: to woo her in person, and is kindly received by her; she,

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: however, begs him, if he values his life, to leave the

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: court. He returns to Normandy, resolved to win her by

Poem Title: M. P. N.
M. P. N.
line: Tale XII. Herwic, being forbidden by Hettel to woo his daughter,

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: invades his kingdom, and, after a battle, Gu-drun, with

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Hettel's consent, is betrothed to him.   630-667.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Tale XIII. Siegfried, a rival suitor for Gu-drun, invades the

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: land of Herwic, who sends to Hettel for his assistance:

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Hettel with many of his vassals comes to his help.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Siegfried is driven into a castle, and there besieged.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
M. P. N.
line: Tale XIV. Hettel sends to announce to Hilda, his wife, and to

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Gu-drun, his daughter, his success in the fight with

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Siegfried. Hartmut, the Norman, takes advantage of the

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: absence of both Hettel and Herwic, and invades the

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Hegeling kingdom.   725-752.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Tale XV. Hartmut sends messengers again to Gu-drun to ask her

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: hand, and threatens to take her by force if she still

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: rejects his suit. She answers that she is betrothed to

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Herwic, and refuses him. Hartmut and Ludwig bring an army

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: and capture the Hegeling castle, and carry away Gu-drun

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: with her hand-maidens.   753-809.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Tale XVI. Hettel and Herwic, being informed of their losses by

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Hilda, make peace with Siegfried, and release him on

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: condition that he will unite with them in war against

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Hartmut. They take possession of the ships of a pilgrim

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: band, and pursue Hartmut.   810-846.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Tale XVII. Ludwig and Hartmut, on their way to Normandy with

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Gu-drun, stop at a desert island, called Wulpensand;

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Hettel and Herwic, in pursuit, reach the island, and a

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: battle ensues.   847-879.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Tale XVIII. Ludwig, king of the Normans, slays Hettel, and his

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: army steals away with the maidens in the night. The

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Hegelings discover their departure, bury the dead, and

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: erect a hospital and cloister in their memory.   880-918.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Tale XIX. The Hegelings return, and announce to Queen Hilda the

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: death of her husband and their ill-success. They decide

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: to wait till the young knights become old enough for war,

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: and then to make a second campaign against the Normans.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
M. P. N.
line: Tale XX. The Normans reach their land with Gu-drun and her

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: maidens; she refuses to marry Hartmut, and is placed in

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: the care of Gerlind, his mother, who treats her harshly

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: and obliges her to perform menial service. Ortrun, the

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: sister of Hartmut, shows kindness to Gu-drun.   951-1040.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Tale XXI. Gu-drun receives better treatment, but, still refusing

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: to marry Hartmut, she is sent to wash clothes on the

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: seashore. Hildeburg, one of her maidens, obtains

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: permission to share her labors, which are continued

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: through many years.   1041-1070.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Tale XXII. Hilda summons her vassals to make an expedition

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: against the Normans. After visiting the graves of their

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: kinsmen on the Wulpensand, they pass in safety the

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: magnetic rocks at Givers, and arrive on the coast of

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Normandy.   1071-1141.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Tale XXIII. Herwic and Ortwin, the brother of Gu-drun, agree to

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: go forward in advance to procure intelligence in regard

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: to her and her maidens.   1142-1164.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Tale XXIV. While Gu-drun and Hildeburg are washing on the

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: seashore, a swan announces to them the approach of Queen

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Hilda's army for their rescue, and tells them that two

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: knights will come the next morning to inform them still

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: further of this.   1165-1206.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Tale XXV. Herwic and Ortwin, coming in a boat, see the maidens

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: washing on the shore, recognize them, and make themselves

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: known. Thinking it dishonorable to take the maids away

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: without winning them in fight, the knights return to

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: bring their army. The maidens go back to Gerlind, and,

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: feeling sure of her speedy rescue, Gu-drun pretends to

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: agree to Hartmut's suit, and is restored to favor.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
M. P. N.
line: Tale XXVI. On their return to their friends, Herwic and Ortwin

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: make known the result of their search. The Hegeling army

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: arrives before the Norman castle, and is discovered by

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Ludwig and Hartmut.   1335-1365.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Tale XXVII. Hartmut names to Ludwig the banners of the coming

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: knights. On learning that the Hegeling army is

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: approaching, Gerlind counsels her son, Hartmut, to await

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: a siege; but he chooses to sally forth, with Ludwig and

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: their followers, and a battle ensues, in which Ludwig

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: overthrows Herwic.   1366-1440.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Tale XXVIII. Herwic, feeling mortified that Gu-drun from the

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: castle should see his fall, returns to the fight, and

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: slays Ludwig. Gerlind bribes one of her men to put

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Gu-drun to death, but he is prevented by the threats of

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Hartmut. Hartmut is taken prisoner, and carried on board

Poem Title: M. P. N.
M. P. N.
line: Tale XXIX. The Hegelings obtain possession of the castle, and

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: spare neither old nor young. Ortrun seeks refuge with

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Gu-drun, and Gerlind also implores her protection, but

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: she is recognized and killed by Wâ-te. The Hegeling army

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: devastate the land: Hartmut and Ortrun are held captive.

Poem Title: M. P. N.
M. P. N.
line: Tale XXX. The Hegeling army returns home, bringing Gu-drun and

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: her maidens, with the Norman captives. Hilda welcomes the

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: returning ships, and embraces her daughter, whom she does

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: not at first recognize, after her long absence. By

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Gu-drun's request, Hilda is reconciled to Hartmut and

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: Ortrun, and Ortwin takes Ortrun for his bride. Hartmut

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: and his men are set free, on their promise not to escape,

Poem Title: M. P. N.
line: and Hartmut agrees to wed Hildeburg. Herwic's sister is
